s.text: Patients with autosomal dominant limb girdle muscular dystrophy type 1C, caused by mutations in caveolin-3 [ 19, 20], or autosomal recessive LGMD2B, caused by mutations in dysferlin, show normal dystrophin and sarcoglycan-sarcospan complex staining patterns [ 21].
CFEOM1 patient and normal muscle sections from extraocular muscle were stained with anti-human sarcospan and anti-human spectrin antibodies.
We have refined the previously published genomic structure of sarcospan more fully and screened for mutations in six families with CFEOM1.

This study was approved by the Children's Hospital institutional review board, and informed consent was obtained from all adult participating subjects and from parents or legal guardians of participating minors.
A sarcospan null mouse has recently been generated and appears to display a normal phenotype [ 22].
Reactions were analyzed on agarose gels and scored for presence or absence of the appropriately sized product.
There may, for example, be a homologous tetraspanin protein that compensates for the absence of sarcospan in mice, but not in humans.
There is, of course, also a difference between complete absence of a protein and a protein with an altered sequence.
There may, for example, be a homologous tetraspanin protein that compensates for the absence of sarcospan in mice, but not in humans.
